      </a>
      <img src="http://images.gibson.com.s3.amazonaws.com/Site-Images/Breadcrumbs/BreadCrumbs-Arrow-Endcap.jpg"/>

     <div id="ArticleContent">
      <div class="ArticleViewer">
       <div class="article-info">
        <div class="headline">
         10 Great Left-Handed Guitarists
        </div>
        <div class="article-publisher">
         Russell Hall
        </div>
        <div class="article-pipe">
         |
        </div>
        <div class="article-date">
         07.14.2008
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class="LikeBar">
        <div id="GooglePlusOne">
         <script src="https://apis.google.com/js/plusone.js" type="text/javascript">
          { lang: 'en-US' }
         </script>
         <g:plusone count="true" size="standard">
         </g:plusone>
        </div>
        <div id="FacebookLike">
         <fb:like action="like" colorscheme="light" layout="standard" show_faces="false" width="450">
         </fb:like>
        </div>
       </div>
       <div class="article-text">
        <br/>
        So uncommon is the phenomenon, you cant help but be taken aback at the sight of a guitarist playing his instrument in left-hand fashion. Fact is, however, southpaw six-stringers occupy several high spots on the list of all-time guitar greats. The 10 below, listed in no particular order, rank among the best.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <span style="font-weight: bold;">
         <img align="right" alt="Tony Iommi" height="328" src="http://images.gibson.com/Lifestyle/English/aaFeaturesImages2008/toni iommi 2.jpg" title="Tony Iommi" width="250"/>
         <br/>
         <br/>
         Tony Iommi
        </span>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        Quite rightly, Judas Priests Rob Halford once introduced
        <a href="/news-lifestyle/features/en-us/tonyiommionearlyblacksabb.aspx" target="_blank">
         Tony Iommi
        </a>
        as the man who invented the heavy metal riff. With his ever present
        <a href="/en-us/Divisions/Gibson%20USA/Guitars/SG%20Specials/SG%20Standard/" target="_blank">
         SG
        </a>
        , the Black Sabbath maestro established the gloomy, minor key patterns and foreboding blues-based solos that continue to define the darker side of the genre. Few guitarists have uncovered more permutations within a singular, self-imposed approach.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <span style="font-weight: bold;">
         <img align="left" alt="Jimi Hendrix" height="263" src="http://images.gibson.com/Lifestyle/English/aaFeaturesImages2008/jimi hendrixxx.jpg" title="Jimi Hendrix" width="350"/>
         <br/>
         Jimi Hendrix
        </span>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        No one saw more possibilities for the electric guitars place as rocks central instrument than
        <a href="http://www.jimi-hendrix.com/" target="_blank">
         Jimi Hendrix
        </a>
        . Utilizing blues and jazz as his springboard, Hendrix pushed his instrument to places his peers could hardly have imagined. Interestingly,
        <a href="http://www.santana.com/" target="_blank">
         Carlos Santana
        </a>
        once speculated that Hendrixs style may have been partly rooted in his Native American heritage.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <span style="font-weight: bold;">
         <img align="right" alt="Elliot Easton" height="375" src="http://images.gibson.com/Lifestyle/English/aaFeaturesImages2008/elliot_easton.jpg" title="Elliot Easton" width="250"/>
         <br/>
         Elliot Easton
        </span>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        Catchy as they were, Rick Ocaseks neurotic pop songs wouldnt have been the same without
        <a href="http://www.gibson.com/en-us/Lifestyle/Video/Elliot%20Easton%20Talks%20About%20Grow/" target="_blank">
         Elliot Easton
        </a>
        s economical leads and spot-on, song-serving solos. Trained at the Berklee College of Music, Easton brought a Beatles-like touch to such Cars classics as Just What I Needed and My Best Friends Girl. Fittingly, Gibson honored him with his own
        <a href="http://www.gibsoncustom.com/inspiredby/ElliotEastonSG.html" target="_blank">
         signature SG
        </a>
        .
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <span style="font-weight: bold;">
         <img align="left" alt="Kurt Cobain" height="244" src="http://images.gibson.com/Lifestyle/English/aaFeaturesImages2008/kurt-cobain-feat.jpg" title="Kurt Cobain" width="358"/>
         <br/>
         Kurt Cobain
        </span>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        Sometimes lost in the near-universal praise for
        <a href="http://www.nirvana-music.com/" target="_blank">
         Kurt Cobain
        </a>
        s songwriting is the fact that the
        <a href="/news-lifestyle/features/en-us/Influences%20_%20Inspirations_%20Nir.aspx" target="_blank">
         Nirvana
        </a>
        leader was also a superb guitarist. Enchanted with both pop music and punk rock, Cobain used his instrument to express his love for both those genres. His playing during Nirvanas
        <span style="font-style: italic;">
         MTV Unplugged
        </span>
        appearance, in particular, showed the finesse that lay just beneath his stormy exterior.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <span style="font-weight: bold;">
         <img align="right" alt="Albert King" height="368" src="http://images.gibson.com/Lifestyle/English/aaFeaturesImages2008/3_albert_king_1.jpg" title="Albert King" width="300"/>
         <br/>
         Albert King
        </span>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        Revered by the likes of Eric Clapton and Stevie Ray Vaughan,
        <a href="/news-lifestyle/features/en-us/Albert%20King_s%20Masterpiece%20at%204.aspx" target="_blank">
         Albert King
        </a>
        was the first major blues guitarist to establish a rapport with R&amp;B and rock audiences. Recording for the Stax label in the 60s, King perfected a blues sound that was spiked with large doses of Memphis soul. In 1968 he became the first blues guitarist to play the legendary Fillmore West venue.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <span style="font-weight: bold;">
         <img align="left" alt="Paul McCartney" height="301" src="http://images.gibson.com/Lifestyle/English/aaFeaturesImages2008/paul-mccartney-photo.jpg" title="Paul McCartney" width="200"/>
         <br/>
         Paul McCartney
        </span>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        In addition to being the most melodic bass stylist in rock history,
        <a href="http://www.paulmccartney.com/" target="_blank">
         Paul McCartney
        </a>
        has unveiled spectacular six-string artistry on countless occasions. Acoustic classics such as Yesterday and Blackbird remain essential for aspiring guitarists who give equal weight to brilliant songwriting and impeccable technique. Its a measure of his talent that in live performance McCartney makes such material look deceptively easy.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <span style="font-weight: bold;">
         <img align="right" alt="Dick Dale" height="302" src="http://images.gibson.com/Lifestyle/English/aaFeaturesImages2008/dick dale.jpg" title="Dick Dale" width="200"/>
         <br/>
         Dick Dale
        </span>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        As the King of the Surf Guitar,
        <a href="http://www.dickdale.com/" target="_blank">
         Dick Dale
        </a>
        exerted a profound influence on 60s groups such as the Beach Boys and Jan and Dean. No less important, his trademark single-note staccato technique had a tremendous impact on such virtuoso players as Eddie Van Halen and even
        <a href="/news-lifestyle/features/en-us/TrueAdventuresInRockJo_4.aspx" target="_blank">
         Pete Townshend
        </a>
        . Dales use of exotic, Middle Eastern scales was daring for its time as well.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <span style="font-weight: bold;">
         <img align="left" alt="Otis Rush" height="296" src="http://images.gibson.com/Lifestyle/English/aaFeaturesImages2008/OTISRUSH.jpg" title="Otis Rush" width="300"/>
         <br/>
         Otis Rush
        </span>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        Characterized by long bends and jazz-tinged arpeggios,
        <a href="/news-lifestyle/features/en-us/otisrushsdoubletroublest.aspx" target="_blank">
         Otis Rush
        </a>
        s style was a vital component of what eventually became known as West Side Chicago Blues. Like Albert King, Rush played a right-hand guitar turned upside down, an approach that contributed to his distinctive sound. Echoes of his style can be heard in the likes of
        <a href="http://www.buddyguy.net/" target="_blank">
         Buddy Guy
        </a>
        and Luther Allison.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <span style="font-weight: bold;">
         <img align="right" alt="Tim Armstrong" height="244" src="http://images.gibson.com/Lifestyle/English/aaFeaturesImages2008/tim armstrong.jpg" title="Tim Armstrong" width="250"/>
         <br/>
         Tim Armstrong
        </span>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        Few hardcore punk guitarists have assimilated as many different styles as
        <a href="http://www.myspace.com/rancid" target="_blank">
         Rancid
        </a>
        s Tim Armstrong. Taking the
        <a href="http://www.ramones.com/" target="_blank">
         Ramones
        </a>
        as his starting point, the versatile musician has incorporated ska, New Orleans music, and even hip-hop rhythms into his various side projects. Like one of his favorite bands, the Clash, Armstrong continually seeks to add texture and color to his punk-centric base.
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        <span style="font-weight: bold;">
         <img align="left" alt="Al McKay" height="210" src="http://images.gibson.com/Lifestyle/English/aaFeaturesImages2008/al mckay.jpg" title="Al McKay" width="200"/>
         <br/>
         Al McKay
        </span>
        <br/>
        <br/>
        From 1973 till 1981,
        <a href="http://www.almckay.com/" target="_blank">
         Al McKay
        </a>
        was the driving instrumental force in the explosive funk sound of
        <a href="http://www.earthwindandfire.com/" target="_blank">
         Earth, Wind &amp; Fire
        </a>
        . Few knew, but McKay had honed his six-string skills years earlier during a lengthy tenure with the Ike and Tina Turner Revue. His trademark rhythm style also graced albums by such disparate artists as Isaac Hayes, Sammy Davis Jr., and the Jackson Five.
       </div>
      </div>
